metadata.case_name: Badri Prasad v. State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: On December 24, 1956, respondent No. 2 purchased at public auction by Divisional Forest Officer, Harda, the cut timber and arkat trees of Coupe No. 9 Eastern, East Kalibhit Range, Harda Forest Division, for Rs. 70,200. Appellant stood surety for respondent No. 2.
Purchase price to be paid in four instalments per para 4 of deed of contract: Rs. 17,600 at once (paid), others due March 1, May 15, December 15, 1957.
Respondent No. 2 did not pay other instalments; State (respondent No. 1) proceeded against appellant as surety.
Contractor to commence work within 1 month after boundary certificate. Exhibit D-1 furnished February 5, 1957; appellant signed as witness. Work to continue up to June 30, 1958.
Interest at 6-1/4% per annum on unpaid instalments. Removal per specified routes, checked at depots per clause 5.
Clauses 5A, 5B: Contractor to set apart timber for agriculturists/villagers till 3 months before expiry.
Forest Contract Rules part of contract per clause 6. Formal deed signed by Chief Conservator May 3, 1957; preamble dates contract May 3, 1957.
First Schedule: Forest produce - all standing trees bearing hammer mark... all felled trees marked at butt end/stumps (signed Dec 24, 1956).
Trace of coupe signed Nov 29, 1956. Third Schedule (outturn register) signed Dec 24, 1956 by resp2, appellant, DFO.
Security bond signed by appellant Dec 29, 1956; DFO March 30, 1957; countersigned Chief Conservator May 3, 1957.
Coupe divided into sections A,B,C,D per r.18 Forest Contract Rules.
Resp2 began operations in section A last week Feb 1957. Defaulted 2nd instalment due March 1, 1957; paid April 25, 1957.
Notice Ex.P4 March 23, 1957: removal exceeds deposit; pay 2nd instalment or stop removal.
April 25, 1957: Forest authorities told appellant no further removal due to default; licence book/transit pass taken back.
Fire broke out; cut timber burnt. Report Ex.D2 April 29, 1957 signed by contractor and Forest Guard.
Resp2 did not pay 2nd,3rd,4th instalments. Goods in B,C,D not removed, ceased to exist due to fire.
Appellant averred in plaint para 5A: possession per section on payment of each instalment.
Plaint para 5B: No right to remove till hammer marked, licence/transit pass checked.
Plaint para 5C: Carry to depots for check, special hammer mark, else unlawful to remove.

legal_issues.text: Whether property in cut timber in sections B, C, D passed to respondent No. 2 before fire in last week of April 1957
Whether Divisional Forest Officer reserved right of disposal under r.8 Forest Contract Rules, attracting s.25(1) Sale of Goods Act
Whether contract signed by Chief Conservator after fire could be effective or ratified

petitioner_arguments.text: No possession/transfer of property in timber sections B,C,D as not put in possession except section A; no delivery till instalments paid per understanding para 5A plaint
Goods not specific as not hammer-marked; delivery only after processes in 5B,5C,5D
Deed signed May 3, 1957 after fire; no ratification possible after goods ceased to exist
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England para 415 p.177

petitioner_arguments.text: R.8 Forest Contract Rules reserves right of disposal till conditions fulfilled, s.25(1) Sale of Goods Act applies
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Forest Contract Rules r.8; Sale of Goods Act s.25(1)

respondent_arguments.text: Admitted paras 5B,5C; denied para 5A understanding on sectional delivery
Property passed per contract terms and rules; specific goods with hammer marks

court_reasoning.text: Goods specific: felled trees had butt mark and stem mark; omission of further marks does not make unascertained
court_reasoning.key_observation: Felled trees sold were specified goods

court_reasoning.text: No contract term restricting possession/delivery of B,C,D till instalments paid; r.18 regulates operations, not linked to payments
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contractor could operate entire property per rules

court_reasoning.text: Chief Conservator's signature May 3, 1957 relates back to auction Dec 24, 1956; per instructions in Forest Manual
court_reasoning.key_observation: Formal signature completes execution, relates back; contract from Feb 5, 1957 to June 30, 1958

court_reasoning.text: R.8 does not reserve right of disposal; statutory lien per s.83 Forest Act; instalments deemed full payment at delivery
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.20 Sale of Goods Act applies: unconditional contract for specific goods in deliverable state, property passes on contract

court_reasoning.text: Ratification possible even after loss, akin to marine insurance; no prejudice to third party; r.32 no compensation for fire loss
court_reasoning.key_observation: Provisional acceptance subject to risks like fire

holdings.text: Property in goods passed to buyer (respondent No. 2) when contract made, per s.20 Sale of Goods Act
No reserved right of disposal; r.8 enforces lien, not contractual disposal right; s.25(1) inapplicable
Chief Conservator's signature relates back; ratification valid post-loss

precedents_cited.case_name: Williams v. North China Insurance Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Ratification of insurance contract possible after loss known
General rule on ratification time; exception for marine insurance post-loss

statutes_cited.name: Indian Sale of Goods Act, 1930
statutes_cited.relevance: S.20: property passes on unconditional contract for specific goods; s.25(1) held inapplicable

statutes_cited.name: Indian Forest Act, 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: First charge/lien on forest produce for payable money; basis for r.8

statutes_cited.name: Forest Contract Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulate operations, payments, no reserved disposal; no compensation for fire loss

statutes_cited.name: Central Provinces Berar Forest Manual
statutes_cited.relevance: Marking rules, contract execution, relation back, auction procedures

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court correctly reversed trial court decree and dismissed appellant's suit for declaration of no liability as surety and injunction against recovery proceedings.

key_quotes.text: Where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property in the goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Application of s.20 Sale of Goods Act, key to holding property passed

key_quotes.text: His formal signature on the deed of contract relates back the contract to the date of auction...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains effect of delayed Chief Conservator signature

key_quotes.text: We are therefore of opinion that the appellants suit has been rightly dismissed by the High Court. We accordingly dismiss the appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
